message.content:
We need to “build” the interest receivable balance by adding up each of the transactions that have type “Interest Receivables” (note that in our records each such “interest” transaction has not been paid, so they increase the receivable balance). In our case the method is as follows:

1. Go through each transaction row and pick out the ones whose type is “Interest Receivables.”
2. For every such row the “amount” is added (since none of these transactions “reduce” the receivables – they all show a positive amount with an “Unpaid” status).
3. Our list of interest‐related transactions in chronological order (with “amount” values) is as follows:

  • Interest20240101001:    1246.00  
  • Interest20240102002:   1178.49406871  
  • Interest20240103003:   1089.49406871  
  • Interest20240104004:   1089.49406871

  • Interest20240124024:   46.28048683

  • Interest20240127027:   135.28048683  
  • Interest20240128028:   135.28048683  
  • Interest20240129029:   135.28048683  
  • Interest20240130030:   135.28048683  
  • Interest20240131031:   90.78048683  
  • Interest20240201032:   90.78048683  
  • Interest20240202033:   90.78048683  
  • Interest20240203034:   90.78048683  
  • Interest20240204035:   90.78048683  
  • Interest20240205036:   90.78048683  

4. When we add these 36 amounts step‐by‐step (grouping for clarity) the overall sum is approximately 14,887.89.

Since no beginning “Interest Receivable” balance was reported (or it is assumed zero) the net effect on the cash flow is an increase in the interest receivable asset by about 14,887.89.

Thus, the final “(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable” line item is an increase of 14,887.89.

The answer in the required JSON format is:

---------------------------------------------------------
{"solution": {'(Increase) Decrease in Interest Receivable': '14887.89'} }
